subject: Re: [junit] Is Junit-based testing REALLY possible for commercial software development ?
msgSnippet: ... Do commercial projects not also need to deliver high-quality systems quickly? ... This assumes that testing requires extra time. Very good testing means
messageBody:
frank zou wrote:

> After lots of reading and trying, I think I understand the following
> benefits that Junit-base testing can give us:
>
> * more robust system
> * clean / good design
> * less regression bugs
> * confidence to do refactorying, especially at the later phase of the
> project.
> * and lots more...
>
> These are really good things, for open-source projects where there is
> no deadline pressure and resource could almost be thought as
> un-limitted. However, for commercial software development, is this
> still possible ?

Do commercial projects not also need to deliver high-quality systems
quickly?

> Although I knew JUnit and other JUnit-based open-source tools for a
> couple of years, my company and team never really enbrace it. The
> major reason is Product Managers always want to add cool features to
> the system quickly while programmers find the schedule is always too
> tight to spend any extra time to write testing.

This assumes that testing requires extra time. Very good testing means
very few defects, which means less overall cost to deliver the same
software. It is important to compare the cost of the /entire/
development process, and not just the cost of typing code.

> I know from the mail list and books that we can take lots of advantage
> of JUnit-based testing, I myself have no real hands-on experience on
> it. So here are my questions:
>
> * Will Junit-based testing make the project time longer or shorter ?
> Any hard statistic data ? ( Here I mean commercial project rather than
> open-source project. )

This depends on your time horizon. How far ahead are you planning? To
use JUnit effectively requires investment in learning. If you are
diligent in learning, you will see positive return on the investment,
but not immediately.

For a plain Java project (not J2EE), I have a team with 3 programmers
who report positive overall return on investment after 3 months.

For a J2EE project, it often takes longer. At least 6 months and maybe 1
year.

Of course, these numbers are based on my informal observations and are
not hard, scientific or statistical data.

> * One intersting point I found is that after Junit-based testing is
> introduced, programmers tend to use IDE debugger much less than
> before. This would save lots of time. Is that true ?

I only use the debugger to step through code without enough tests. In
the equivalent of the past 3 months, I have spent less than 1 hour in
the debugger. It is a big time savings for me.

> * Some guys say JUnit is good for biz / util code testing. But for web
> application development, where HTML/javascript would be root cause of
> lots of bugs, Junit is not so powerful. Any comments ?

I don't believe that's true, but that doesn't matter. Even if I assume
it is true, most of the high-priority defects in projects I coach are
business logic problems, so if we eliminate 70% of those, we have a lot
of time to figure out how to test HTML and Javascript. (_JUnit Recipes_
already provides a lot of advice on testing J2EE components and
applications. Also Google "Test-Driven J2EE".)

> * How can I convince managers and programmers that JUnit-based is
> really possible for commercial software development ? Any differnece
> from open-source projects ?

What does it mean for JUnit to be possible? What results do they expect?
